title: 111_hr4680
content: The "Jobs Momentum Act of 2010" may reduce the employer portion of payroll tax for certain employers increasing payroll. The "Jobs Momentum Act of 2010" reduces employer payroll tax deposits by a percentage of payroll increase for certain employers in 2010 and 2011. Definitions and rules apply. The "Jobs Momentum Act of 2010" reduces employer payroll tax deposits by a percentage of payroll increase for certain employers in 2010 and 2011. Definitions and rules apply, including qualified wages and inflation adjustments. The "Jobs Momentum Act of 2010" reduces employer payroll tax deposits based on a percentage of payroll increase for certain employers in 2010 and 2011. Qualified wages are defined as employee wages not exceeding $32,000, and inflation adjusted qualified wages are determined by multiplying qualified wages by the cost-of-living adjustment for the relevant calendar year. The "Jobs Momentum Act of 2010" reduces employer payroll tax deposits based on a percentage of payroll increase for certain employers in 2010 and 2011. The amount of any deduction allowable to the employer under chapter 1 of the tax code for taxes paid with respect to employment during any calendar quarter shall be reduced by the employer payroll tax deposits. Adjustments for certain acquisitions are also addressed under regulations prescribed by the Secretary. The "Jobs Momentum Act of 2010" addresses reductions in employer payroll tax deposits based on payroll increases for certain employers in 2010 and 2011. It also includes provisions for adjustments related to acquisitions and dispositions of trade or business units after December 31, 2009. The "Jobs Momentum Act of 2010" includes provisions for adjustments related to acquisitions and dispositions of trade or business units. The employer must provide necessary information to the acquiring person for applying the section after the disposition. The amount of wages deemed paid by the employer before the disposition will be reduced for subsequent calendar quarters. The Secretary of the Treasury will prescribe rules for employers not on a quarterly system. The Treasury will provide rules for eligible employers not making quarterly income tax deposits.
